title: 105_s282
content: The Act is known as the "Olympic Commemorative Coins Act" and defines terms like "Corporation" and "Secretary" for the purposes of the Act. It establishes a Commemorative Coins Program. The "Olympic Commemorative Coins Act" mandates the issuance of biannual Olympic coins with specific specifications before the Summer or Winter Olympic Games held outside the US. Additionally, an expanded multi-coin commemorative coins program is to be developed by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees for games held in the US. The "Olympic Commemorative Coins Act" requires the issuance of biannual Olympic coins with specific specifications before the Summer or Winter Olympic Games held outside the US. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant committees, will develop an expanded multi-coin commemorative coins program for games held in the US. During the first 2 months of each coin-issuance period, the Secretary cannot issue other commemorative coins. Sales of the coins will include surcharges, with funds going to the Corporation for the Amateur Sports Act of 1978. The design for each coin issued under the "Olympic Commemorative Coins Act" shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Corporation. Each coin shall include a value designation, year inscription, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". Additional symbols, emblems, and names may be included with the consent of the Corporation. The Corporation has the exclusive right to use symbols, emblems, trademarks, and names under the "Olympiad" section. The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender, sourced from appropriate sources for silver and gold, and sold at a determined price. Each coin issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coin, surcharge, cost of designing and issuing the coin, and estimated profit. SEC. 7. The Secretary determines costs and profit for coins issued under this Act, with no judicial review allowed. SEC. 8. Waiver of procurement regulations for goods and services needed by the United States Mint. SEC. 9. Audits and reports required. SEC. 9. The Comptroller General can audit the Corporation's expenditure of funds received under section 3(e)(1). The Corporation must submit a biannual report to Congress and the Secretary accounting for these funds. SEC. 10. Congress expects each coin edition to be self-sustaining without costing the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund.
